SentenceText: I'd only put require inside the constructor if it was a dynamic dependency, like const wordlist = require(./config/lang/${lang}.json).
You can use session storage if you want the data to be retrieved once PER SESSION or local storage if you want to have better control of the data's "expiration".

regarding sending app to background , the content won't reset if the app is left working by IOS , but if closed you will get a new launch when you open it again with array content is initiated from the begining

fetch returns a Promise, so if you want to use slice method, you should use it inside the last .then(), but it would be better if you fetch your data in componentDidMount, save your data in React state, and after that use in render method;
I'd only put require inside the constructor if it was a dynamic dependency, like const wordlist = require(./config/lang/${lang}.json).
